name: Myanmar
currentCrisisSummary:
Myanmar suffers multiple, overlapping catastrophes inflicted by its **military state**: a nationwide civil war against the junta that seized power in 2021, and the **ongoing genocide and persecution of the Rohingya minority**. The post-coup conflict pits a broad revolutionary movement against the Tatmadaw (military), which employs **extreme brutality against civilians** nationwide.

This widespread violence follows the **2017 genocidal campaign against the Rohingya**, involving mass killings, systematic rape, and the forced expulsion of nearly a million people to Bangladesh, where they remain stateless refugees. The state's long history of **denying Rohingya citizenship**, a direct result of **colonial-era 'divide and rule' tactics** and post-colonial nationalism, laid the groundwork for this ethnic cleansing. The post-coup war and the Rohingya crisis create mass displacement and **severe, multi-faceted human suffering**, exacerbated by **geopolitical indifference and impunity** for the military regime.

colonialRoot.legacy: British colonial policy created the fissures that define Myanmar's modern conflicts. Through 'divide and rule', Britain administered the Bamar lowlands separately from ethnic 'Frontier Areas', institutionalised ethnic identities, and used minorities in the colonial army, deepening divisions. Crucially, the British encouraged labour migration from Bengal into Arakan (Rakhine), including many Rohingya. After independence, the new state's nationalist project framed the Rohingya as 'illegal Bengali migrants', weaponising colonial-era resentments and British administrative legacies to deny their identity and ultimately render them stateless. This colonial architecture of ethnic hierarchy and division was inherited and ruthlessly exploited by the post-colonial military.

historicalContext.title: The Military as a State Within a State
historicalContext.description: For over 60 years, the Tatmadaw has operated as a state within a state, functioning as a privileged political and economic class. Through massive military-owned conglomerates (MEHL and MEC), it controls vast swathes of the economy. The 2021 coup was a violent move to protect this entrenched economic empire from democratic oversight.

historicalContext.title: State-Sponsored Persecution and Rohingya Statelessness
historicalContext.description: The post-colonial state institutionalised discrimination against the Rohingya, culminating in the 1982 Citizenship Law, designed to legally erase their existence by refusing to recognise them as an official ethnic group. This act of legal violence rendered them stateless in their homeland, stripped them of all fundamental rights, and formalised their status as a people to be persecuted with impunity.

historicalContext.title: Ethnic Cleansing and Genocidal Violence Against the Rohingya
historicalContext.description: Decades of discrimination erupted into systematic, state-directed violence, particularly in 2012 and 2017. The 2017 military 'clearance operations' were a premeditated campaign of mass killing, gang rape, and village destruction, terrorising the Rohingya into fleeing en masse. This violent expulsion, driving over 750,000 to Bangladesh, is now the subject of a genocide case at the ICJ.

historicalContext.title: Khaki Capitalism and the Failed Transition
historicalContext.description: The decade of quasi-civilian rule (c. 2011-2021) was a period of military-managed neoliberal reform ('khaki capitalism'). Foreign investment often partnered with military conglomerates, modernising their empire under a civilian facade. The NLD government failed to challenge the military's power or its repressive, Bamar-centric state, culminating in Aung San Suu Kyi defending the military's genocide against the Rohingya at the ICJ.

historicalContext.title: Post-Coup Revolution and Ethnic Solidarity
historicalContext.description: The 2021 coup ignited a nationwide revolution, forging fragile solidarity between the Bamar majority and many long-oppressed ethnic minorities. The shared experience of the Tatmadaw's brutality has forced many Bamar democrats to confront the military's history of atrocities against ethnic peoples, including the Rohingya, creating potential for a new, federalist vision.

historicalContext.title: Geopolitical Indifference and Impunity
historicalContext.description: Myanmar's military regime has been shielded from accountability. China and Russia use their UN Security Council vetoes to block strong action, protecting strategic investments. Western sanctions have lacked sufficient pressure, and ASEAN's non-confrontation policy has effectively normalised the military's crimes, including the Rohingya genocide.

historicalContext.title: International Law and Accountability
historicalContext.description: Formal accountability efforts are underway but face political obstacles. The Gambia's ICJ case accuses Myanmar of violating the Genocide Convention concerning the Rohingya. The ICC is investigating potential war crimes and crimes against humanity related to both the Rohingya and post-coup violence. These processes are vital for challenging state impunity.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement (Post-Coup)
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 3 million people internally displaced since 2021, forced to flee **junta air strikes and ground assaults.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees (Rohingya)
humanitarianImpact.description: Nearly 1 million Rohingya confined to camps in Bangladesh after fleeing the **2017 genocide**, still **denied citizenship and safe return by the Myanmar state.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees (Post-Coup)
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of thousands forced into neighbouring Thailand and India by the **junta's post-coup terror campaign.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties (Rohingya Genocide)
humanitarianImpact.description: Est. 24,000 Rohingya killed during the **military's 2017 genocidal operations**, with thousands subjected to sexual violence.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties (Post-Coup)
humanitarianImpact.description: Thousands of civilians killed directly by the junta since 2021, with total deaths far higher due to **conflict-driven collapse of health and livelihoods.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population (Total)
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 18.6 million people require aid due to the **nationwide devastation caused by military rule, civil war, and economic collapse.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Around 12.9 million face acute hunger resulting from **conflict disrupting supply chains and the junta's weaponisation of aid.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: The health system has collapsed, **systematically targeted by the junta** with hundreds of attacks on hospitals and medical staff.

timeline.event: **Burmese Conquest of Arakan**: The independent Kingdom of Arakan is conquered by the Burmese Konbaung dynasty. This violent conquest leads to the forced displacement of many Arakanese people and marks the beginning of intensified Bamar rule over the region, altering the existing ethnic dynamics.

**British Conquest of Burma**: Over three successive wars, the British Empire gradually conquers and annexes the Burmese kingdom, integrating it into British India and establishing the colonial framework that would reshape the region's ethnic and political landscape.
**British Annexation of Arakan**: Britain encourages labour migration from Bengal, including Rohingya, laying demographic groundwork for future conflict.
**Independence**: Burma gains independence, facing ethnic insurgencies and beginning to exclude the Rohingya from the national identity.
**First Military Coup**: General Ne Win begins decades of isolationist, authoritarian military rule.
**Citizenship Law**: Myanmar's military government enacts a law omitting the Rohingya from recognised ethnic groups, formally rendering them stateless.
**8888 Uprising**: A popular uprising is brutally crushed by the military, killing thousands.
**The 'Opening' / Khaki Capitalism**: A period of quasi-civilian rule and neoliberal reform begins, allowing the military to modernise its economic empire.
**Sectarian Violence in Rakhine**: Organised violence kills hundreds of Rohingya and displaces over 140,000 into internal camps.
**Rohingya Genocide**: The Tatmadaw unleashes 'clearance operations', forcing over 750,000 Rohingya to flee genocidal violence to Bangladesh.
**ICJ Genocide Case**: The Gambia files a case against Myanmar at the ICJ concerning the genocide against the Rohingya.
**Coup & Revolution**: The military annuls election results and stages a coup, triggering a nationwide armed revolution.
**Operation 1027 & Shifting Tides**: Coordinated offensives by ethnic armies inflict stunning defeats on the junta, shifting the war's momentum.

donate.description: A grassroots network supporting civil disobedience strikers, local aid groups, and community resilience projects inside Myanmar.
A multi-ethnic humanitarian service movement providing emergency medical care, shelter, food, and documentation of atrocities in conflict zones.
Provides emergency aid, including food, water, and shelter, to Rohingya refugees fleeing persecution.

advocacy: Demand a comprehensive global arms embargo against the junta.
Call for coordinated international sanctions on military leaders and their economic networks (MEHL & MEC).
Support the pro-democracy National Unity Government (NUG) and ethnic resistance organisations.
Advocate for robust cross-border humanitarian aid bypassing the junta.
Support international accountability efforts, including the ICJ genocide case (Rohingya) and ICC investigations (post-coup war crimes).
Oppose premature or forced repatriation of Rohingya refugees until their citizenship, safety, and rights in Myanmar are guaranteed.
Amplify Rohingya voices and support Rohingya-led organisations advocating for their rights.

reading.title: The River of Lost Footsteps: A Personal History of Burma
reading.description: Thant Myint-U's sweeping history tracing the deep historical forces shaping Myanmar's crises.

reading.title: First, They Erased Our Name: A Rohingya Speaks
reading.description: A powerful memoir by Habiburahman detailing the lived experience of persecution and statelessness as a Rohingya.

reading.title: The Rohingyas: Inside Myanmar's Hidden Genocide
reading.description: Azeem Ibrahim's account of the long history of persecution leading to the 2017 atrocities against the Rohingya.
